org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint

Class RopeJoint

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.dyn4j.dynamics.Constraint
      • org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint.Joint
        • org.dyn4j.dynamics.joint.RopeJoint

  • public class RopeJoint
extends Joint
    Represents a maximum/minimum length distance joint.

    Given the two world space anchor points, the Bodys are not allowed to separate past the maximum distance and not allowed to approach past the minimum distance.

    NOTE: The respective setLimits(double), setLimits(double, double), setLimitsEnabled(boolean), setLimitsEnabled(double), setLimitsEnabled(double, double), setLowerLimit(double), setLowerLimitEnabled(boolean), setUpperLimit(double), and setUpperLimitEnabled(boolean) methods must be called to setup the maximum and minimum limits, otherwise this joint acts like a DistanceJoint.

    Nearly identical to Box2d's equivalent class.

    Since:
    2.2.1
    Version:
    3.1.5
    Author:
    William Bittle
    See Also:
    Box2d

    • Constructor Detail

      • RopeJoint

        public RopeJoint(Body body1,
         Body body2,
         Vector2 anchor1,
         Vector2 anchor2)
        Minimal constructor.

        Creates a rope joint between the two bodies that acts like a distance joint.

        Parameters:
        body1 - the first Body
        body2 - the second Body
        anchor1 - in world coordinates
        anchor2 - in world coordinates
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if body1, body2, anchor1, or anchor2 is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if body1 == body2

      • shiftCoordinates

        protected void shiftCoordinates(Vector2 shift)
        Description copied from class: Constraint
        Shifts (translates) the coordinates of this constraint.

        Typically this method should not be called directly. Instead use the World.shiftCoordinates(Vector2) method to move the entire world.

        Specified by:
        shiftCoordinates in class Constraint
        Parameters:
        shift - the distance to shift along the x and y axes

      • setLimitsEnabled

                    double upperLimit)
        Sets both the lower and upper limits and enables both.
        Parameters:
        lowerLimit - the lower limit in meters; must be greater than or equal to zero
        upperLimit - the upper limit in meters; must be greater than or equal to zero
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if lowerLimit is less than zero, upperLimit is less than zero, or lowerLimit is greater than upperLimit

      • setLimitsEnabled

        public void setLimitsEnabled(boolean flag)
        Enables or disables both the lower and upper limits.
        Parameters:
        flag - true if both limits should be enabled
        Since:
        2.2.2

      • setLimits

        public void setLimits(double limit)
        Sets both the lower and upper limits to the given limit.

        This makes the joint a fixed length joint.

        Parameters:
        limit - the desired limit
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if limit is less than zero
        Since:
        2.2.2

      • setLimitsEnabled

        public void setLimitsEnabled(double limit)
        Sets both the lower and upper limits to the given limit and enables both.

        This makes the joint a fixed length joint.

        Parameters:
        limit - the desired limit
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if limit is less than zero
        Since:
        2.2.2
